title: Hip Rotation
subtitle: Learn to rotate — the secret to power in your punches.

steps.text: Stand with your feet parallel and slightly wider than shoulder-width. Stretch your arms out to your sides like the image. This drill works for both orthodox and southpaw stances.
Push your bum back, slightly bend your knees, and engage your core. Keep your body relaxed but upright.
Rotate your hips left and right. Imagine a stick running from your head to the ground keeping your spine upright. Slightly lift your heel to allow smooth rotation.
Side view: when rotating, stay upright and avoid leaning forward or back. Use your hips to initiate the twist and feel your core working.

takeaways: Power comes from hip rotation, not your arms.
Stay upright — rotate without leaning, keeping your core engaged and body relaxed.
Lift your heel slightly when turning to let your hips move freely.

title: Mechanics of Straight Shots
subtitle: Build power and protection into every straight punch.

steps.text: Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width, bum slightly back, knees bent, and hands in guard position. Elbows rest on your body, chin tucked.
Twist your hips to the right while extending your left arm. Slightly lift your left heel to release your hip. Keep your other hand in guard.
Repeat on the other side: rotate to your left and punch with your right. Fist moves in a straight line from your chin and turns over at the end.

takeaways: Power in straight punches comes from hip rotation and proper timing, not just your arm.
Relax your punching hand until midway, then clench and turn it parallel at full extension.
Keep your other hand and elbow in place to protect your chin and body.

title: Mechanics of Hooks
subtitle: Master the hook — power and precision in one motion.

steps.text: Start in stance: feet wider than shoulder-width, hands in front of face, chin tucked. Engage your core and bend your knees slightly.
Rotate your hips to the right while keeping your left arm in position. Feel tension build in your hips.
From that position, swing your left arm into a hook. Thumb up, forearm parallel to the floor. Opposite hand stays in guard.
Repeat for right hook: load your hips first, rotate, and strike with a compact motion. Avoid swinging past your centerline.

takeaways: The hook’s power comes from hip rotation — load your hips first.
Keep your forearm parallel to the floor, thumb up, and your opposite hand protecting your chin.
The hook stays tight — don’t let it swing too far past your body.

title: Mechanics of Uppercuts
subtitle: Master the uppercut — they’ll never see it comin’!

steps.text: Stand in your boxing stance: feet wide, core engaged, bum back, hands up in guard, chin tucked.
Shift your weight onto your lead leg by hinging at the hips. Your shoulders should tilt slightly, preparing you to drive upward.
Let your punching hand drop slightly out of your guard, keeping your elbow in close to your body.
Rotate your hips and drive your arm upward into the punch. Exhale as you strike and keep your other hand in guard.

takeaways: Shift your weight to your lead leg and hinge at the hip to load the punch.
Drop your punching hand slightly, then rotate your hips and punch upward.
Keep your opposite hand protecting your chin and breathe out as you punch.
